history.content:
Do it if you want to do it, say if you're really passionate about some coursework or research work. If your goal is just to make more money in industry then I don't know if doing a masters will add much value to you (most technical roles for bachelors and masters tend to be fairly similar). 

It's definitely not too late to start thinking about it as a junior. You can apply in the fall of your senior year.

children.subject:
Totally in the same boat as you, junior studying CS. I am not planning to go to grad school at the moment. Like Anon Mouse said above, I think it is worth it if you like research, and it might not be worth it if you just want to make more money. 

I had the chance to talk to a professor about this, and my question was that even if we choose to go into the industry as undergrads, it is not like we would be stuck with what we learned in college for the rest of our lives. We will and probably have to keep learning anyway, so what is the difference between going to the industry and pursuing a higher degree? 

The response included some old adages about passions and interests, but he also mentioned that in the industry one would have more exposure to the current best practices, and if one master them one could undoubtedly make huge impacts this way, but only in academia could one have the time and resources to come up with the next generation product. This is far, far down the road and maybe we never need to worry about it, but I thought it is a nice perspective to have. 

The rest are just my personal opinions: I am not super confident in the current state of the tech industry or the economy as a whole. We all know how much harder it has gotten to get a job as an SDE compared to 5 years ago, so maybe I should just secure a spot for myself while I can?
You should look for research positions as well. The official application for 5th years deadline is spring. As long as you have a research advisor, you would be fine.
What is a research advisor? Is it basically a professor who has a research and you are in his/her team?

I'm current in a position where I might have not taken enough upper level course works to know if I am passionate about course work materials or if I wish to just jump right into the industry. I will start my internship this summer and see if the industry is something that I wish to do, but for some programs such as fifth year at berkeley, won't it be too late to apply at that point?

Thank you! In terms of industry masters, what exactly is that? This is a new term for me and I would be nice if you can give some examples. Also, tbh I don't know why  I want to do masters. It just feels like school went by so fast for the past two years and I feel like I have not learned a lot to be ready to go into the industry yet.

In terms of research experience, I am specifically talking about the fifth year program at berkeley and I'm wondering if it is necessary to have prior experience to apply or else my profile won't be so compelling.

Industry masters is a term that I use to describe programs that are centered around preparing for the industry. MSAII at CMU, Berkeley's MEng program, Berkeleys 5th year MS in Data Science are all examples of this. Basically, all masters programs that are labeled with "MEng" are industry masters by this definition.

Berkeley's 5th year CS masters program is what I'd classify as research focussed since the expectation is that you complete a thesis with a professor. Just my take, but I've heard for this program if you've already been working with a professor, then you are basically guaranteed to get in. It definitely isn't necessary to have prior research experience, I think plenty of people have gotten in without it, but having it certainly puts you in a better position.
Can I apply to both 5th year MS and 5th year MEng programs at Berkeley? Or is that not allowed?
I will choose one of them, but trying to understand if we are allowed to apply to both and then go into whichever we get into.
@Anon Poet, why do you say MEng programs tend to be cash grabs? If you do MEng from Berkeley, instead of the 5th year MS, do you think that industry will perceive MEng as "inferior" to the MS?

I say MEng programs tend to be cash grabs since most of them charge high tuition costs for the program. If you take a look at most MEng programs, they tend to cost $50k or more for tuition. Even public schools like Berkeley aren't exempt from this and use these programs for funding.

Again, I'm not in a hiring position so I can't speak too much about whether or not industry will perceive MEng as "inferior", but to my understanding, you can kind of view it a few ways: MEng programs do tend to be less "prestigious" because of how some of them are if you pay you'll get in, but there are also plenty that are very selective while also causing a dent in your wallet, CMU's "cash grab Masters programs" and Berkeley's MEng program that I list above are examples of this. Additionally, there is the benefit of saying that you went to a prestigious school for a masters degree, and since the MEng programs are industry-focussed you would also have that "advantage" over traditional research MS degrees.

TLDR: industry probably doesn't care, you can still say you have a master's from ____.

Just to follow up on this, I think you should be asking yourself the reasons why you want a master's in CS. Is it for money? for research? to learn more? As stated in a previous comment, if it's for money, 2 years in the industry will likely be > starting salary with a master's degree. One thing to note is that there are also industry masters and research masters degrees with emphasis respectively. Industry masters tend to be cash grabs.

Also, specifically for master's, research experience is nice, but not necessary. A lot of master's programs in CS have research as optional. I just got into UCSD's master's in CS without any research experience! It's different for PhD though since it'll be harder without research experience.

I can offer a bit of an alternative perspective: I did research in RISE and also had standard industry internships @ FAANG/Unicorns, I ultimately decided research wasn't for me. Like what many other posters said, assuming your end goal is industry, the 1 additional YOE from just going into industry with a bachelors will outweigh the masters degree, unless you want to do a very specific role in ML or something (and even then it will be mostly Ph.D. grads doing the REAL ML). Furthermore, at least for me, I felt research was often times a lot of head bashing against something and was not rewarding, while in industry depending on your company the impact is more tangible and the feedback loop is quicker (papers take a while to be published, pr's are pretty quick). Hope this helps!

history.content: I'm currently a junior studying CS and a lot of my friends are planning on doing masters. I don't know if it is too late for me to start preping now since it requires research experiences and stuff... Also, in general, I don't even know if I should stay in school and get a masters degree. I kinda feel lost and any advice from people with this type of experience would be nice...
history.subject: Masters or no...
